docs.lead_paragraph: FOR those parents frantically beating the pavements to find yet another pack of $5.99 Pokemon cards, take heart: your children are unwittingly demanding a healthy dose of Japanese values. Pokemon, the army of feisty, funny, fantastic cartoon creatures that has become a smash hit among the under-10 crowd in the United States and will star in the first Pokemon movie, opening Friday, stands to become one of Japan's biggest, most successful cultural exports.

headline.main: Japanese Family Values: I Choose You, Pikachu!

docs.abstract: World of Pokemon cartoons reflects Japanese values--responsibility, empathy, cooperation, obedience, respect for elders and humility; these values are admired but not always handsomely rewarded in American society and culture; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: FOR those parents frantically beating the pavements to find yet another pack of $5.99 Pokemon cards, take heart: your children are unwittingly demanding a healthy dose of Japanese values.    Pokemon, the army of feisty, funny, fantastic cartoon...

docs.lead_paragraph: I was gamely sitting through the second bone-crunching, blood-gushing hour of ''Fight Club'' the other night when I found myself involuntarily wondering how much damage the movie was doing to society. For most Beltway types, this is a sadly automatic spasm. A similar thought tends to flit through my mind when watching a late night rerun of Jerry Springer, or the latex melodrama of cable wrestling. After Tipper Gore and Bill Bennett, watching mindless violence just isn't any fun anymore. In fact, if I hadn't already read that very week that violent crime had just plummeted to yet another record low, I might even have sustained my unease. But then I had one of those extremely rare ''Hey, wait a minute'' epiphanies and wondered whether I hadn't gotten it exactly the wrong way around.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 11-07-99: Counter Culture; The Assault on Good News

docs.abstract: Andrew Sullivan article says there is something in America, or at least American politics, that refuses to accept good news, whether it is drops in crime, teenage pregnancy and unemployment or studies showing that Vietnam veterans, victims of child abuse and people dropped from welfare rolls have an unexpected resiliency in face of their difficulties (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Naomi Wolf, the feminist writer turned feminist campaign consultant, disputes the notion that she has been giving Al Gore secret lessons in how to bare his teeth, growl and get elected leader of the pack. In fact, Ms. Wolf calls the whole idea that she has been instructing him on how to be a dominant ''Alpha male'' rather than a subordinate ''Beta male'' a total fantasy.

headline.main: Naomi Wolf, Feminist Consultant to Gore, Clarifies Her Campaign Role

docs.abstract: Naomi Wolf, feminist writer turned campaign consultant, disputes notion that she has been instructing Vice Pres Al Gore on how to be dominant 'Alpah male' and how to dress; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Nov. 1 front-page article ''School a Rare Luxury for Rural Chinese Girls'' points to a problem that is global in scope. In its 1998 report to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, the Nongovernmental Organizations Working Group on Girls expressed the need for major improvement in retention of girl students, particularly teenage girls ''who drop out in high numbers because of marriage, exploitative labor, poor health, sexual abuse, pregnancy or poor quality and irrelevance of their education.''
docs.abstract: Letter from Sister Clare Nolan, a nongovernmental representative at United Nations, says Nov 1 article on girls in China dropping out of school points to problem that is universal in scope

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas on the importance of teaching morality in schools: I want to make the case for moral education. Teaching is more than training, and learning is more than literacy. Our children must be educated in reading and writing, but also in right and wrong.
docs.abstract: Excerpts from third campaign speech on public education by Republican Presidential frontrunner, Texas Gov George W Bush (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Personal Health column of Oct. 19 (''Brain Tumors: Elusive, Varied and Not Always Deadly'') advised pregnant women to take vitamin A supplements. While in theory this may prevent future cases of brain cancer, excessive intake of vitamin A may cause devastating birth defects. Doses greater than 10,000 international units have been reported to cause malformations in one epidemiologic study. If the vitamin A contained in the standard prenatal vitamin is combined with a supplement, this threshold can easily be exceeded.
docs.abstract: Dr Stephen T Chasen opposes October 19 Personal Health column suggesting that pregnant women take vitamin A to prevent brain cancer; holds large doses of vitamin A may cause birth defects
